The 'American bison' (Bison bison), also commonly known as the 'American
buffalo', is a North American species of bison that once roamed the grasslands
of North America in massive herds, became nearly extinct by a combination of
commercial hunting and slaughter in the 19th century and introduction of bovine
diseases from domestic cattle, and has made a recent resurgence largely
restricted to a few national parks and reserves. Their historical range roughly
comprised a triangle between the Great Bear Lake in Canada's far northwest,
south to the Mexican states of Durango and Nuevo LeÃ³n, and east to the Atlantic
Seaboard of the United States (nearly to the Atlantic tidewater in some areas)
from New York to Georgia and per some sources down to Florida.
Retrieved on February 24, 2013.

Two subspecies or ecotypes have been described: the plains bison (Bison bison
bison), smaller in size and with a more rounded hump, and the wood bison (Bison
bison athabascae)âthe larger of the two and having a taller, square
hump. Furthermore, it has been suggested that
the plains bison consists of a northern (Bison bison montanae) and a southern
subspecies, bringing the total to three. However, this is
generally not supported. The wood bison is one of the largest wild species of
bovid in the world, surpassed by only the Asian gaur and wild Asian water
buffalo. It is the largest extant land animal in North America.
